headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I just add maybe quickly, that might very useful. So we guided 7% revenue growth for Connected Car for fiscal '17. Actually, you have to consider 4% to 5% in a whole as APR. So for us to have 7% growth, we need to have right around 10%, 11% total grow
componenttext: Can I just add maybe quickly, that might very useful. So we guided 7% revenue growth for Connected Car for fiscal '17. Actually, you have to consider 4% to 5% in a whole as APR. So for us to have 7% growth, we need to have right around 10%, 11% total growth. So that means we'll have roughly about 2% to 3% production, which is a reasonable assumption. And 5% to 6% of our growth will come from a take rates, which is pretty much in line with that, if industry will go from 27 to 30 or 31, a 3% to 4%, so that will mean 4% to 6% -- 5% to 6% for us to achieve our 7%. And then remaining 3% to 4% is the program expansion. So add them all altogether it becomes right around 7% to 10% or actually 8% to 11%, take out the APR, that gives you 6% to 8% range, which is about 7% midpoint. That's what we've guided.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we've talked a lot about that bottom end of the pie, terms of that being where the real growth can be over the next say decade in terms of where you can penetrate more. Obviously in the kind of luxury high-end segment, you have always enjoyed a really
componenttext: So we've talked a lot about that bottom end of the pie, terms of that being where the real growth can be over the next say decade in terms of where you can penetrate more. Obviously in the kind of luxury high-end segment, you have always enjoyed a really nice competitive advantage. So where do you think, when you go down to that bottom half of the pie, do you feel like that will be more competitive over the next decade in terms of trading accounts wins and where do you think then the advantage comes from in terms of having that relationship with some of those OEs as those bottom tier systems convert?

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So 2 things. First of all, because we're playing in display audio, that doesn't mean that our margins would be under pressure. Display audio does not require complex R&D and display audio is pretty much final result of our scalable platform approach. So w
componenttext: So 2 things. First of all, because we're playing in display audio, that doesn't mean that our margins would be under pressure. Display audio does not require complex R&D and display audio is pretty much final result of our scalable platform approach. So we develop our platform and we can actually implement that on multiple programs with some adaptation. So we are able to protect our margins, and we have done that over the years. However, coming back to our sweet spot, is actually mid-segment. That's where we supply full blown embedded system with many of other things. Now we are also adding to that telematics and many other products. And that's where margins are good because we are bringing lot of value and new technology. So all in all, if you look at our total backlog of just Connected Car, that is double-digit profit margin in that. And when you start to through the revenue lines, scale does help. And by the way, we continue to take cost reduction programs, which is a way of life. There is nothing new we announced. So with that said, we feel very comfortable in further margin expansion in this business and also we're selective of what we take. We don't take any business. We will generally walk away if the business does not meet out requirement. And you have heard that from me many, many times. And we had actually shown that in our results that we are very margin savvy and protective.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough. And then question on services side. It sounds like you're getting some wins when you start looking to '19 and can start to actually see some real revenue and some real adoption of these technologies. Could you talk a little bit more abo
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. And then question on services side. It sounds like you're getting some wins when you start looking to '19 and can start to actually see some real revenue and some real adoption of these technologies. Could you talk a little bit more about that curve as this moves from a little bit pie in the sky the reality in terms of moving just from a nice to have a must have? And what the real evidence of that adoption curve looks like? And then also your desire to utilize that technology beyond even the auto sector?

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Good one. In our services business, we support -- our biggest business is automotive, then we have also 2 other verticals, the telecom, which is also kind of merging more and more into auto side. And then we have enterprise software development. Bu
componenttext: Right. Good one. In our services business, we support -- our biggest business is automotive, then we have also 2 other verticals, the telecom, which is also kind of merging more and more into auto side. And then we have enterprise software development. But staying with overall connected business, analytics is going to play big. We have 1500 data scientists in our company, which a lot of people don't realize. We are powerhouse in data. And data analytics will be big deal in automotive industry. Second, Redbend we acquired, put it in our services business. I said earlier, we have already over $150 million software backlog, with 75% of operating margin in it as a start to go to the bottom end to the revenue line, you will see margin expansion. And by the way, this is a very fast development of orders. We have almost more than a dozen OEMs signing up for OTA technology. And half of those dozen are directly HARMAN customers. Other half are actually going through other Tier 1s because this technology to any So all in all, service looks pretty promising. And that was the rational we had and I think we're seeing great opportunities for growth.

componenttext: So Brad, first of all, thanks for question. I don't think we break out Display Audio revenue or telematics revenue, unless as we start to report in our reporting system. And that's why what we saw exactly after transition in year '13, we saw '14, '15, '16 double-digit growth in Connected Car, and same thing we think is going to happen after transition year of '18.

And that's really working out well for us.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first of all, one thing which we pride as a team, management team, is execution. We are very, not fancy about strategy and we just love doing execution. This business has couple of fundamentals, which got a little bit out of track. And I think we are b
componenttext: So first of all, one thing which we pride as a team, management team, is execution. We are very, not fancy about strategy and we just love doing execution. This business has couple of fundamentals, which got a little bit out of track. And I think we are bringing those back. Started with leadership and then channel management and cost leadership, and then launching new products, which will fit in the segments we're focusing, that's the government and corporate and entertainment enterprise. This business is going to be 3% of growth this year and come back to nearly 14% EBITDA, which is getting close to its historic level. And as far as the portfolio is concerned, look, this is a discussion. I invite my Board of Directors to debate and discuss every year once a year, and we talk about everything. What should we bring in, what should be not have it in eventually, and we will take that discussion as time comes. Whatever is the best for our shareholders, we will always do that, you can be sure of that.

componenttext: Excellent. So before we conclude the call today, let me just remind you that the auto industry is rapidly evolving. And we have been building a portfolio of integrated technologies that lead the industry in intelligent connectivity, which is a prerequisite for autonomous driving. Together with our consumer audio, Professional Solutions and Connector Services business, we have set a target to exceed $11 billion in revenue 2021. And I feel good about it. We have a stable team. And with that, I would like to thank you, to our owners, investors, and the analyst community for your support and the work you do to the HARMAN story. We look forward to meeting you in upcoming conference or roadshow. And with that, I wish you all a great day. Thank you.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the HARMAN Fiscal Fourth Quarter 2016 Earnings Call [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded today, Thursday, August 4, 2016. I will now turn the conference over
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the HARMAN Fiscal Fourth Quarter 2016 Earnings Call [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded today, Thursday, August 4, 2016. 
I will now turn the conference over to Yijing Brentano, Vice President, Investor Relations and Strategy. Please go ahead.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thank you for joining our fourth quarter and full year fiscal year 2016 investor call. I'm joined in Stanford today by Dinesh Paliwal, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and by Sandy Rowland, our Chief Financ
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thank you for joining our fourth quarter and full year fiscal year 2016 investor call. I'm joined in Stanford today by Dinesh Paliwal, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and by Sandy Rowland, our Chief Financial Officer. If you haven't done so already, I invite you to visit the Investors section of our website, where you can download copies of our earnings release and the supporting slide presentation that we will be referencing today. 
Before Dinesh and Sandy provide their remarks on the quarter, let me remind you that certain statements during this conference call and question-and-answer session may be forward-looking in nature as defined in the United States Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements are based on management's beliefs, assumptions and current expectations but are subject to a number of important risk factors and uncertainties, which have been fully described in the press release that we issued this morning. 
Now let me turn the call over to Dinesh.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Yijing, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I am pleased that this morning we announced very strong results for the fourth quarter and full year. Our fourth quarter results came in stronger than our forecast, with net sales increasing 12% t
componenttext:
Thank you, Yijing, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I am pleased that this morning we announced very strong results for the fourth quarter and full year. Our fourth quarter results came in stronger than our forecast, with net sales increasing 12% to $1.9 billion. We expanded our operating margins and delivered a 20% year-over-year improvement in EBITDA and a 14% year-over-year improvement in earnings per share. 
We successfully mitigated the supply chain disruption in our automotive business following the recent earthquake in Japan, and we capitalized on increased demand for our consumer audio products in May and June. In addition, our business in China had a strong finish, with record full year revenue of approximately $800 million, up nearly 20% from the prior year. I'm also pleased that the Professional Solutions division achieved our Q4 target on top and bottom line. 
The fourth quarter caps another banner year for HARMAN. Revenue, EBITDA and earnings per share all reached record highs. We exceeded $6.9 billion in revenue, an increased of 16%, excluding foreign exchange. EBITDA improved 23% to $836 million, and we grew earnings per share by 13% to $6.24. 
I am pleased to report that our automotive backlog now stands at $24.1 billion. Our technology leadership and ability to successfully deploy intelligent connected solutions for the car that are safe and secure is resonating with customers. Not only did we win next-generation business from existing customers, we added new automakers to our customer list. Over the last 2 years, we have added $11 billion of new automotive awards. That is momentum. Our record automotive backlog of more than $24 billion provides HARMAN a strong foundation for long-term growth. 
Now let me take a closer look at our divisions and review some recent notable achievements. Let's start with our Connected Car division, which is highlighted on Slide 7 of your investor presentation. During the quarter, we secured several new and follow-on awards to provide connected car solutions for customers, including Harley-Davidson, Porsche, Toyota and a North American automaker. Advancing our telematics strategy, we secured an award from a premium German automaker for an industry-first solution for the main gateway to the car, providing a unique connectivity platform. 
This solution integrates the power expended -- this solution integrates, that -- powers the expanded telematics features and enables system diagnostics, remote control capabilities and system software updates. The automaker will also employ HARMAN's cloud-based over-the-air update technology, ensuring that critical software fixes, feature additions and upgrades can be easily and squarely and safely transmitted and added to the vehicle while on the road, not only for HARMAN head units but also for onboard ECUs from other Tier 1 suppliers. This comprehensive gateway platform is an industry first. HARMAN is the only supplier with these proprietary technologies to create this end-to-end solution. 
A product like this is a perfect example of how our bolt-on acquisitions are paying off. We strategically expanded our capabilities in over-the-air update technology, cybersecurity, cloud applications and data analytics. And when we combine these with our own deep expertise in connectivity technologies, we can create unique solutions for our customers that are smart, safe, secure and real-time updatable. 
We continue to receive accolades for our industry leadership. In June, HARMAN was named Supplier of the Year at the Automotive Interior Expo, in Stuttgart, Germany, highlighting our competence in embedded infotainment and telematics solutions. Also, in Consumer Reports' most recent guide to infotainment systems, the highest rated system is designed and built by HARMAN as well. 
Now turning to Lifestyle Audio division. Some of our recent notable achievements are highlighted on Slide 8 of the investor presentation. During the quarter, HARMAN won new business awards with Hyundai, Kia, Audi, Lexus, Subaru, SGM Wuling in China and Toyota. In addition, we secured our first award for our premium Summit audio platform with an electric vehicle company. This scalable Summit platform provides the foundation to integrate the best of HARMAN's sound processing and sound management technologies, along with new features like Connected Jukebox and Virtual Venues, to create an unprecedented in-car audio experience. As further proof of HARMAN's leadership in the industry, we won a Ford World Excellence Award for our Revel audio system in Lincoln vehicles. 
Turning to consumer audio. As I mentioned earlier, we finished a very strong quarter, with increasing demand of our award-winning products due to great design and expanded distribution channels. For the year, we won a total of 56 design and innovation awards across our consumer audio portfolio. Let me also remind you that we have been selected by Lufthansa to provide our noise-canceling headphones across their fleet. 
Now turning to the Professional Solutions division. In May, we appointed  Mohit Parasher as the President for the division. Mohit is a seasoned leader with more than 20 years of experience growing audio, video and system business throughout Asia, Middle East and Europe. Mohit brings a new level of energy and sense of urgency to Professional Solutions business. 
Last year, we implemented our enterprise and entertainment solutions-based go-to-market strategy, and we took cost actions in Europe. This year, we are focused on taking additional steps to improve cost structure in North America. We are already seeing encouraging signs of momentum in the enterprise segment. Not only have we booked several significant awards in corporate, government and education markets, we will also launch a number of integrated solutions to support these focused verticals. We expect these actions will help restore professional to historic levels of growth and profitably. Some of the notable wins and events for the quarter are highlighted on Slide 9 of the investor presentation. 
Now turning to the Connected Services division, highlighted on Slide 10 of your presentation. During the quarter, we secured several awards to provide software services for BMW, FCA, Microsoft, PSA and Reliance. In addition, we partnered with NXP Semiconductors to jointly offer new software gateway solutions to the automotive market. We continued to capitalize on our industry-leading, cloud-based OTA software update technology, winning awards from leading OEMs, such as FCA, Porsche and Subaru. We now have over $150 million in OTA software auto backlog, and about half of it is in the automotive space covering over a dozen OEMs and growing. 
In summary, this was a year of record across the board at HARMAN. Our success in 2016 demonstrates our team's ability to execute and deliver profitable growth. You will recall, in 2013, we set out an ambitious plan to grow HARMAN revenues to $6 billion by '16. Today, we reported almost $7 billion in revenue and more than doubled our 2013 EBITDA. This morning, we have also provided financial guidance for 2017 and presented a longer-term outlook. Our CFO, Sandy Rowland, will provide you the details later. 
As we look forward, we see significant growth opportunities across all the divisions. In the automotive space, the industry is experiencing an unprecedented social and technological transformation, fueled by increasing intelligent connectivity and supported by autonomous vehicles, electrification, and urban mobility. The car is getting an upgrade as never seen before. HARMAN is well positioned to capitalize on each of these trends. 
Let me remind you, our portfolio of integrated technologies now include embedded infotainment solutions ranging from Display Audio to an intelligent compute platform addressing entry, mid and high vehicle classes; enhanced telematics products and gateway solutions; industry-leading cybersecurity; and OTA products for all ECUs, whether HARMAN supplied or non-HARMAN supplied; superior automotive audio technologies like Individual Sound Zones, HALOsonic and Summit; data analytics and back-end software services to complement ADAS development in the industry; and a number of innovations still in our pipeline. We have an end-to-end value proposition that automakers are looking for. Building on our strong backlog of awarded business and track record of execution, we expect continued growth in our automotive revenue. 
At the same time, due to the staggered timing of various automotive program launches and roll-offs, we expect to see lower growth in 2018, followed by strong growth in 2019 and beyond. This is a cycle that is common in our business. We have experienced it before, as recently as 2013. As shown on Slide 14 of our presentation, we experienced accelerated growth for several years after the transition year in 2013. In fiscal 2018, we will continue to ramp up new programs and make R&D investments, both to deliver on the contracts we have won and to capitalize on the major trends we discussed earlier. 
Longer term, we are confident that we will see accelerated revenue expansion from our automotive backlog, higher-margin automotive services and the increasing market demand for Connected Car and autonomous driving technologies. On top of that, there are additional reasons to be excited. With autonomous driving, the in-car audio experience or sound management becomes even more essential. With our record $6.6 billion of car audio backlog and continued growth in take rates, we expect car audio to continue to lead the company in profitability and grow faster than the company average. 
In addition, we have confidence in the turnaround of our professional business. With all the actions we have taken, we are optimistic that we can return margins to historical levels over the medium term. Together with the continued growth in our consumer audio business and increasing opportunities in Connected Services, we are squarely on the path towards achieving our goal of $11 billion in revenue by 2021. 
Now I will turn the call over to Sandy, who will give you additional color on our financial results.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dinesh, and good morning, everyone. Let me walk you through our financial highlights for the quarter and provide additional detail on our outlook for fiscal year 2017 and beyond. As a reminder, most of my financial remarks are provided on an op
componenttext:
Thank you, Dinesh, and good morning, everyone. Let me walk you through our financial highlights for the quarter and provide additional detail on our outlook for fiscal year 2017 and beyond. As a reminder, most of my financial remarks are provided on an operational basis, which excludes acquisition-related items, restructuring and nonrecurring charges. The full reconciliation of our GAAP to our operational results is included in the press release that we issued this morning. This quarter, our revenues were $1.9 billion, an increase of 12% compared to the prior year. Revenue in our Connected Car division increased 11% versus the prior year primarily due to higher take rates and stronger production. Revenue in our Lifestyle Audio division increased 25% compared to the prior year. The increase in net sales was primarily due to higher take rates and the acquisition of Bang & Olufsen automotive in-car audio and higher consumer audio sales driven by continued strong demand for smart audio solutions. Revenue in our Professional Solutions division increased 1% compared to the prior year. Revenue in our Connected Services division increased 7% to $185 million in the quarter compared to $173 million a year ago, primarily due to higher demand for engineering services. 
Total company gross margin increased 110 basis points to 30.5% primarily due to the impact of higher sales volume, leveraging a more efficient fixed production cost based and productivity initiatives. Connected Car gross margin increased 300 basis points to 25.5% and Lifestyle Audio gross margin increased 380 basis points to 35.1%, both benefiting from better leverage of fixed costs, lower warranty expenses and manufacturing productivity. 
Professional Solutions gross margin decreased 340 basis points to 36.7%, driven by product mix and new factory start-up costs in Hungary. In Connected Services, the timing of booked revenue is tied to specific milestones in longer-term engineering projects while expenses are recognized as incurred. This can result in margin volatility. As a result, for the fourth quarter, Connected Services gross margin declined 850 basis points to 28.2%. Beginning in fiscal 2017, we will use percentage of completion accounting for significant new contracts. This is expected to reduce some of the volatility. 
Our SG&A expense as a percentage of net sales increased 20 basis points from the prior year to 20.7%. Connected Car SG&A increased 110 basis points to 14.1% and Lifestyle Audio SG&A increased 20 basis points to 20.2%, both due to higher research and development costs to support awarded business. SG&A expense in Professional Solutions remained in line with the prior year. Connected Services SG&A as a percentage of sales decreased 180 basis points to 18.2% due to better leverage on higher sales. Finally, corporate SG&A as a percentage of sales declined by 10 basis points to 2.3%. 
Putting it all together, our consolidated operating income was $185 million compared to $150 million in the prior year, a 24% increase. Below the line, we had higher income tax expenses in the quarter due to an increase in U.S. tax from deemed income on foreign earnings and jurisdictional mix, resulting in a higher-than-forecasted effective tax rate. EPS was $1.57 compared to a $1.37 in the prior year, up 14%. 
Now turning to the full year. In fiscal year 2016, revenue, EBITDA and EPS all reached record highs for HARMAN. Revenue was $6.9 billion, an increase of 16% excluding foreign exchange. And EBITDA reached $836 million, a 23% increase excluding foreign exchange, and we grew EPS from $5.71 to $6.24, a 13% increase excluding foreign exchange. 
Now let me spend a few minutes on cash and capital allocation. In fiscal 2016, we generated nearly $450 million of cash flow from operations, driven by strong earnings and effective working capital management, and we invested approximately $200 million in capital expenditures. In the fiscal year, we repurchased approximately 1.6 million shares at a cost of $140 million. Combined with $100 million in dividends, we returned a record $240 million to our shareholders, over half of our cash generated from operations. We ended the fiscal year with $602 million in cash. Across the board, this wraps up a solid fiscal year for HARMAN. 
Now let's turn to our guidance for fiscal 2017. First, we are making a slight adjustment to our divisional reporting structure. We will move our aftermarket car audio business from the Connected Services division to the Lifestyle Audio division as this product line shares our consumer go-to-market organization and the consumer product innovation center in Shenzhen China. Slide 16 shows the impact is approximately $60 million in revenue on a full year basis. 
As Dinesh indicated, we are targeting between $7.3 billion and $7.5 billion in revenue for fiscal 27 -- '17 and between $900 million and $940 million in EBITDA. Our forecast is based on a number of key assumptions, namely: global GDP growth of approximately 2.5%, global automotive production growth between 2% and 3%, global industry embedded infotainment take rates increasing from about 27% to 30% and a euro-to-dollar exchange rate of 1.10. We expect top line growth and EBITDA expansion across all 4 division. Furthermore, we expect about $180 million in depreciation and amortization expenses, between $50 million and $60 million in interest expense and miscellaneous charges. And we estimate that our tax rate will be between 27.5% and 28%, and we have assumed a similar level of share repurchase as fiscal 2016. 
Assuming approximately 72 million shares outstanding, our EPS will be between $6.75 and $7. We will remain opportunistic in buying back our shares incrementally to our current plan. We have approximately $360 million remaining on our board-authorized share repurchase program, which runs until October 2017. 
This morning, we also provided a longer-term outlook. Our assumptions regarding the macroeconomic and automotive production environment are similar to our 2017 guidance assumptions. We are targeting a high single-digit revenue CAGR over the next 3 years reaching approximately $8.6 billion in revenue by fiscal 2019. In addition, we expect to grow our EBITDA margins to about 13.5% in fiscal '19, representing a 140 basis point improvement compared to fiscal year 2016. As Dinesh pointed out, we do expect lower revenue growth in fiscal 2018 due to the staggered timing of various automotive program launches and roll-offs. In subsequent years, we'll have a number of new programs reaching full scale, positioning us for accelerated growth. 
In summary, we are pleased with our fiscal 2016 performance. We have set robust targets for fiscal 2017 and the next 3 years, and we are focused on innovation and execution to deliver against these targets. 
Thank you for your attention. Dinesh and I are now happy to take your questions.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ryan Brinkman with JPMorgan.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It looks like you're expecting, as Sandy mentioned, an acceleration in 2019 versus 2018. I'm just curious what is primarily driving that, whether it might relate to a potential single, large contract on the Connected Car side or really just a collection o
componenttext: It looks like you're expecting, as Sandy mentioned, an acceleration in 2019 versus 2018. I'm just curious what is primarily driving that, whether it might relate to a potential single, large contract on the Connected Car side or really just a collection of smaller factors. And then while you're commenting on that, maybe just update us on the most material launches you have coming in Connected Car and relative timing of those contracts, for example, at General Motors, Subaru, the low end infotainment award that was discussed previously, et cetera.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, thank you for your question. So yes, first of all, we're very happy with 2016 record revenue and EBITDA and EPS. And with the great backlog we have, especially, I repeat, $11 billion order bookings in the last 2 years, that gives us momentum. So we
componenttext: Ryan, thank you for your question. So yes, first of all, we're very happy with 2016 record revenue and EBITDA and EPS. And with the great backlog we have, especially, I repeat, $11 billion order bookings in the last 2 years, that gives us momentum. So we are very confident about out years. As we indicated, 2018 directional outlook is a slower growth and, in fact, flattish Connected Car revenue. And that is primarily due to rolling off of some of the programs while we're still ramping up the large programs both in Europe and North America. But they will not be fully at scale. So that's what is reflected in '19 and 2021, double-digit growth, and we have number of North American and even Asian programs coming up, which also have very good margins. So we feel very good about '19, '21. Also, '18 is actually still a good year. We are still growing and still expanding our margins. Let me also mention one highlight which is reflected in our guidance and has impacted '18 slower growth. As you all know, that in North America, we have a great customer in FCA, Fiat Chrysler automotive, and we still supply to them, a large part of infotainment comes from HARMAN. In fact, we are the primary supplier of audio. And in fact, in June, the Consumer Reports even named it as a top infotainment, what Chrysler is using from HARMAN. Having said that, there are multiple suppliers of infotainment to FCA, which I have said in my earlier calls. Based on FCA's current sourcing strategy, our infotainment volume in fiscal '18 may be lower, and it is reflected in our 2018 guidance and beyond. As you are aware, we have won a couple of follow-on awards as well as, over the year, update awards with them for across the car line globally. On top of that, we are also continuing to ship audio and infotainment. And with that said, our strong relationship with FCPA -- FCA, we are well positioned for the next-generation infotainment program, which we expect to be available for bidding in the next 12 to 18 months.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then my next and last question is on the impact, if any, that you see to HARMAN from the potential acquisition of Fiat Chrysler's Magneti Marelli business by Samsung Electronics. I don't think there is much overlap between your 2 business
componenttext: Okay, great. And then my next and last question is on the impact, if any, that you see to HARMAN from the potential acquisition of Fiat Chrysler's Magneti Marelli business by Samsung Electronics. I don't think there is much overlap between your 2 businesses currently, but there has been some speculation that Samsung could perhaps be interested in using Magneti as some sort of launchpad to get into automotive infotainment. So what can you say about the barriers to entry on the embedded side? Or what competitive advantages do you have that you think can keep newer entrants at bay on the embedded side? And then if they were to get into more connected audio, sort of  la Apple, the extent to which that is not necessarily a competitive threat.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, it's a great question. And actually, we should clarify. The Magneti Marelli is a large Tier 1 and very small player in infotainment. In fact, similar to another smaller sort of player in North America, which was up for the sale, which people have pa
componenttext: Ryan, it's a great question. And actually, we should clarify. The Magneti Marelli is a large Tier 1 and very small player in infotainment. In fact, similar to another smaller sort of player in North America, which was up for the sale, which people have passed, Magneti Marelli  has also tried to sell their infotainment business over the last several years. And we have worked with them often on, but they really don't really make a viable player as is. And especially when you think about how fast the space is changing, it's not about traditional instrument cluster or infotainment or basic amplification and speakers. It has moved on to a full connectivity intelligence, over-the-air update, cybersecurity, a scalable end-to-end service platform. It's all about analytics, which we'll partner with the companies like Mobileye, take their sensors' information and create information. So it's the scale, it's the technology, it's the R&D power. So we will see what that means if that acquisition happens, but we see almost no impact on our current or in our near to midterm future.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Patrick Nolan with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Patrick Nolan with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had 2 questions, one longer -- one on the long-term outlook and then maybe one on the outlook for next year. First, on the longer-term margin outlook, could you maybe give us some color on why -- it looks like your guiding to about 30 basis points of ma
componenttext: I had 2 questions, one longer -- one on the long-term outlook and then maybe one on the outlook for next year. First, on the longer-term margin outlook, could you maybe give us some color on why -- it looks like your guiding to about 30 basis points of margin improvement in '17, '18, and then we have close to 80 basis points of a step-up in '19. Is that purely a function of the leverage of the growth? Or is there something else going on? Maybe there's a good amount of launch cost that are constraining the '18 margins. Just any color you can give there on that trajectory would be helpful.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you for your question. I think you pretty much hit it spot on. If you look at what we have guided to from a margin perspective, we're calling for margin expansion from '17 to '18. But it's more muted because the growth is lower between '17 and
componenttext: Yes. Thank you for your question. I think you pretty much hit it spot on. If you look at what we have guided to from a margin perspective, we're calling for margin expansion from '17 to '18. But it's more muted because the growth is lower between '17 and '18. But then when you look at our projections between '18 and '19, we really start growing again on the top line. And as you look out across our entire portfolio, we get very strong leverage on top line growth. So that's the primary reason.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the -- then maybe the nearer-term outlook. So it looks like your guidance is slight revenue growth in the professional services (sic) [ Professional Solutions ] business next year. First off, what gives you confidence in that? And second, is there
componenttext: And on the -- then maybe the nearer-term outlook. So it looks like your guidance is slight revenue growth in the professional services (sic) [ Professional Solutions ] business next year. First off, what gives you confidence in that? And second, is there a good amount of accelerating growth in these projections for '18 and '19 in that professional services (sic)  [ Professional Solutions ] business?

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great question. So let's start with Professional Solutions business, then I'd talk about Connected Services. So first of all, this is a good business. We have built a robust portfolio of audio, video, lighting and automation, and we have expanded our cust
componenttext: Great question. So let's start with Professional Solutions business, then I'd talk about Connected Services. So first of all, this is a good business. We have built a robust portfolio of audio, video, lighting and automation, and we have expanded our customer segment to corporate, government and education beyond traditional recording studios and touring sound. This does -- this has a 4-pronged turnaround strategy, which I feel very comfortable with. The number one starts with leadership, sense of urgency. We have fixed that. Number two, we are addressing channels. Channels, we are going in some markets direct; some, we are going indirect. But we are training the channels to sell the solutions to enterprise and entertainment segment. And the third is cost leadership. You know us in HARMAN. We are really paranoid about cost every year, and automotive is a good training ground. So we already took some very strong actions last year. We shut down 2 factories in Europe in high cost, and we moved into a brand-new factory in Hungary. And that, we already said over 100 basis point of bottom line improvement, which is already starting to happen. So we will have that this year. It will improve. And then, of course, we have whole slew of new integrated products being launched this year, which absolutely are going to fit the segment strategy for corporate, government, education and entertainment and enterprise. So with that said, 130 basis point improvement in fiscal '17 is very reasonable. And 3% top line growth, this is after we already stabilize the business in Q4, we feel very comfortable. Now moving on to Connected Services business. That business actually, if you peel the onion and just take what we acquired in Symphony Teleca, this actually grew almost 14% and actually had margins, EBITDA, also around 14%, 15%. What we did last year, we had 2 pieces added to that business. One was our aftermarket car audio, which actually really belonged to consumer audio. Because if you take that out, this business moves up to nearly 13% -- actually nearly 14% EBITDA, which we have already shown in our slide deck. On top of that, we also acquired last year a company called Redbend, and that company is a great technology within internal business but is in development mode. And we took about $12 million, $15 million bottom line hit for that. So if you adjust for that, our service business actually performed exactly to our deal turns and our expectation, nearly 15%. So expecting 15% margins in '17 and expecting 8% growth is very reasonable target. In midterm, I expect this business to grow at mid -- double digit and also perform mid to high teens bottom line.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris McNally with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris McNally with Evercore ISI.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So could we dive into a little bit of some of those specific programs, in particular, the GM ramp, which starts, I think you said, in a very small way in 2017? But can you kind of discuss the '18, '19 ramp? Sort of if it starts with Cadillac, what are som
componenttext: So could we dive into a little bit of some of those specific programs, in particular, the GM ramp, which starts, I think you said, in a very small way in 2017? But can you kind of discuss the '18, '19 ramp? Sort of if it starts with Cadillac, what are some of the key launches in '18 that follow on?

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Chris, first of all, we are very constrained in terms of naming our customers and timing of their of SOPs. I've made a mistake in the past. I will not do it again. What you just said about the customer, program is going quite well, and we will start in
componenttext: So Chris, first of all, we are very constrained in terms of naming our customers and timing of their of SOPs. I've made a mistake in the past. I will not do it again. What you just said about the customer, program is going quite well, and we will start in '17 with a very small SOP, which we are happy about. And '18 would continue to ramp, but the full scale, we'll achieve in '19, fiscal '19. And that's why we have shown '19 with double-digit growth. And in addition to this program, we have some of the Japanese and other North American and European programs also coming fully ramped up to the scale. So that would create scale, which means a lot to the bottom line, and scale also help us advertise R&D at a larger scale of customers.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a little bit on '18 around the divisions. I mean, if growth is going to be lower on the infotainment, you talked about some of the timing, can you talk about where some of the growth will come in, for example, in Connected Car -- not C
componenttext: Okay. And then just a little bit on '18 around the divisions. I mean, if growth is going to be lower on the infotainment, you talked about some of the timing, can you talk about where some of the growth will come in, for example, in Connected Car -- not Connected Car, sorry, on the services side? Do we start to see a pickup in that division in '18?

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So great question. As we will see almost flattish Connected Car or maybe a slower growth, we will continue to see excellent development in car audio, which is our profit leader in the company and will remain because we have excellent $6.6 billion, double
componenttext: So great question. As we will see almost flattish Connected Car or maybe a slower growth, we will continue to see excellent development in car audio, which is our profit leader in the company and will remain because we have excellent $6.6 billion, double digit, reaching 20%-or-so range, profitability. And there, we see good improvement in take rate, so that will continue to drive. Then we also expect, as we already have 14% EBITDA in our Connected Services business, with Redbend not making losses, hopefully, in '17, we'll be close to 0, breakeven point. That would bring us nearly 15% EBITDA in Connected Services. So it's reasonable to expect in '18 another 100 basis point improvement in the bottom line. Then the third business is professional. This year, we feel pretty good about 3% top line and hitting margin improvement of almost 13.7% or nearly 14%. That business should also reach its historic levels of mid-teens in EBITDA. So all 3 businesses performing quite well. And the fourth one, also performing very well, the Connected Car. Only thing is it will not have the same scale effect, although the same profitability, same good leverage and continue to invest in our R&D on the new programs, which will be ramping up fully in end of '18 and beginning of '19. So all in all, '18 would be a very busy year, very good year, building up for excellent accelerated growth in '19 and onwards.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Leiker with Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Leiker with Baird.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Our plan, as we look out the next 3 years, is that we will continue to see a linear path. So this year, for take rates, we saw that the industry finished right around 27%, and our guide for next year calls for take rates rising to about 30%. And we'v
componenttext: Yes. Our plan, as we look out the next 3 years, is that we will continue to see a linear path. So this year, for take rates, we saw that the industry finished right around 27%, and our guide for next year calls for take rates rising to about 30%. And we've continued the same linear trajectory in our guidance out to '19.

componenttext: Okay. And then do you have how that take rate varies between the premium OEMs and the mainstream?

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So I would just say we see our sweet spot of growth for take rate continues to be the mid-segment car, which is where we have most of our business now, although we continue to see some more improvement in the high-end luxury cars. And we are also s
componenttext: Right. So I would just say we see our sweet spot of growth for take rate continues to be the mid-segment car, which is where we have most of our business now, although we continue to see some more improvement in the high-end luxury cars. And we are also starting to see good development in our Display Audio, where we also have won a large award in North America. And subsequently, we have won several awards actually in Asia and Europe also. So all in all, we will see our participation or take rate would be in Display Audio and mid-segment while we still see some high-end cars.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Tamberrino with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Tamberrino with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First one, just like to -- looking at incremental margin assumptions for Connected Car in 2017. It's look like there's a little bit of a slowdown from the last couple of years, where you're in the 42% range, I think, for FY '16. But now we're going to be
componenttext: First one, just like to -- looking at incremental margin assumptions for Connected Car in 2017. It's look like there's a little bit of a slowdown from the last couple of years, where you're in the 42% range, I think, for FY '16. But now we're going to be in the mid to high teens level at '17. What's providing that somewhat of a drag or step down, if you will, in incremental margins from '16 to '17?

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for your question. I think, first of all, you have to put some of this in perspective. If you look at the margin expansion that we have enjoyed in our Connected Car division over the past 3 years, it's really been fantastic. To hit over 14% EB
componenttext: Yes. Thanks for your question. I think, first of all, you have to put some of this in perspective. If you look at the margin expansion that we have enjoyed in our Connected Car division over the past 3 years, it's really been fantastic. To hit over 14% EBITDA rate this year, 1 year ahead of schedule, we're really pleased about it. So next year, we will see continued margin expansion in Connected Car. And the leverage, while it's just a little bit south of 20%, we do have a lot of new awards in our backlog, so r&D will continue to expand. But net-net, we're very pleased on the margin development in Connected Car.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, if I may, look, this business as an industry is also transforming significantly, and it's a matter of a few more years before you'll see lot more software content and value differently. At the moment, we are in a unique disadvantageous position
componenttext: And David, if I may, look, this business as an industry is also transforming significantly, and it's a matter of a few more years before you'll see lot more software content and value differently. At the moment, we are in a unique disadvantageous position. As a company, we take 4% to 5% of annual price reduction hit every year, and that's not the case with major -- other Tier 1s. However, we are slowly changing that dynamics as more and more software solution we are selling, whether it's a car audio-related software or Connected Car solutions software or even Connected Services by itself. We took a very large software services business recently with a European OEM, which we're very proud about. So I think as you start to see that, you start to see the OTA revenues start to come. And OTA is 75% to 80% margin. So we will start to see some improvement in the out years. But even then, in the next immediate -- in a few years, we still see margin expansion coming in. We're very happy with it.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Now that's very helpful. And then secondly for me, on the Lifestyle Audio segment, it looked like a very strong quarter from the top line. What specifically was driving that? Was there any incremental launch activity on the branded car audio side? W
componenttext: Okay. Now that's very helpful. And then secondly for me, on the Lifestyle Audio segment, it looked like a very strong quarter from the top line. What specifically was driving that? Was there any incremental launch activity on the branded car audio side? Was that more on the consumer audio side? And should we be seeing something similar carrying forward in terms of quarterly cadence in the first half of 2017? Or is that 9% good for the full year?

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So this is a great business, great division. Lifestyle has 2 businesses, almost same, equal $1 billion each roughly. Our car audio business is our profit king in the company. And there, we have nearly -- well, $6.6 billion going into $7 billion aut
componenttext: Right. So this is a great business, great division. Lifestyle has 2 businesses, almost same, equal $1 billion each roughly. Our car audio business is our profit king in the company. And there, we have nearly -- well, $6.6 billion going into $7 billion auto backlog. And here, entry to -- barrier to entry is very high. Once you are in, you are really in with the kind of technology. So there, we continue to see a take rates improvement happen. Margin improvement will continue to help, EPS accretive. And then second business is almost $1 billion also, which is a great scale for consumer audio. Now consumer audio, we have created our own niche. We have smart audio, and smart audio means all wireless, all intelligent, all cloud-based speakers and home audio headphones. And that business has evolved very well. As a matter of fact, just last month, our JBL portable speaker ranked #1 in Europe by research company GfK. And China has started to show great development in terms of their appetite for American branded consumer audio products. So all in all, it did quite well. Q4 came in very strong. Now reminding you, as we go forward, with a $1 billion base in consumer audio, we can grow, if you want, 20% a year. Or we can choose where we want to grow to protect the margin. And I would go for the protecting margins. We are reaching close to 10% now in our consumer audio and almost 20% in car audio. So blended, it's 15%. I want to push more margin-driven growth. That's why our growth targets we have given are very balanced.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Johnson with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Johnson with Barclays.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to return to the topic of growth in Connected Car for '19 over '18 and '18 over '17. When we think about keeping '18 flat in the face of what sounds like some customer roll-offs and then growing in '19, how much of that business is already in the n
componenttext: I want to return to the topic of growth in Connected Car for '19 over '18 and '18 over '17. When we think about keeping '18 flat in the face of what sounds like some customer roll-offs and then growing in '19, how much of that business is already in the new business backlog? And how much is yet to be signed?

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. Brian, first of all, thanks for your question. Typically, we have 100% of revenue in the backlog for the immediate 12 months here. So fiscal '17, we have 100% revenue in our backlog. And 3 years out, which is '19, we have about 75% of the revenue in
componenttext: Good. Brian, first of all, thanks for your question. Typically, we have 100% of revenue in the backlog for the immediate 12 months here. So fiscal '17, we have 100% revenue in our backlog. And 3 years out, which is '19, we have about 75% of the revenue in the backlog. And typically, 5 years out, we will have 50% in the backlog, which makes a lot of sense. That's what gives us good visibility, and of course, we will be booking in -- booking more orders towards 2021 and subsequently.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question, you touched upon your assumptions around embedded nav -- embedded infotainment, but you also mentioned the growth of Display Audio. If a scenario develops where take rates on upper-end Display Audio improve at the expense of, say, m
componenttext: Okay. Second question, you touched upon your assumptions around embedded nav -- embedded infotainment, but you also mentioned the growth of Display Audio. If a scenario develops where take rates on upper-end Display Audio improve at the expense of, say, mid-level infotainment with embedded nav, because I could argue with that. Sort Display Audio, optional nav coming through Apple CarPlay gets you pretty close to mid-level infotainment with embedded nav. Just how are you positioned for that trend? What do you have in each category? And what kind of assumptions are you making vis--vis kind of the OEM kind of the showroom mix around those products in 2018, 2019?

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So Brian, first of all, let's go back to our picture, which we have been sharing with you. There's a pie. And if you divide the pie into half, the bottom half of the pie is basically traditional AM/FM radio or really nothing, just a hole. And the to
componenttext: Okay. So Brian, first of all, let's go back to our picture, which we have been sharing with you. There's a pie. And if you divide the pie into half, the bottom half of the pie is basically traditional AM/FM radio or really nothing, just a hole. And the top half of the pie, you divide into 2 quadrants. The left quadrant, we have traditionally said it is the embedded infotainment, and other quadrant is the Display Audio. So what we are witnessing, and we already saw a similar development last year, the bottom half of the pie is transforming either into Display Audio or into embedded infotainment. My personal thesis is, based on a lot of discussions with OEM, if we all believe that we're going towards autonomous or semi-autonomous driving, cars cannot be run from devices in your hand or in the pocket. Then you will need to have a strong compute platform in the car, sensors, technology and various other things in it. Therefore, even Display Audio is a intermediate step to go towards fully embedded system. So in the near term or midterm, 5, 7 years, Display Audio will actually almost come from the nothing, AM/FM and so will an embedded infotainment. 60%, 65% embedded infotainment in 4 to 5 years is pretty much everybody's take right now. So we would actually benefit and enjoy both types -- size of the pie growing. We are into Display Audio. We are also into entry systems, mid systems and the high systems. So we'll grow both. While, at the same time, you mentioned CarPlay. We are actually implementing CarPlay. We are implementing and tried Google AutoLink. We are also implementing Baidu CarLife and few other things. So these are all smart apps we'll implement on all the systems as we go forward.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, wouldn't those -- and are those implemented on embedded infotainment as well?
componenttext: Well, wouldn't those -- and are those implemented on embedded infotainment as well?

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As well, absolutely right. So it's the choices OEMs want to offer that, look, you buy a car and you may have 4 members in the family, and if you think about shared economy, you cannot design a car just for CarPlay or just for Baidu or just for Google. So
componenttext: As well, absolutely right. So it's the choices OEMs want to offer that, look, you buy a car and you may have 4 members in the family, and if you think about shared economy, you cannot design a car just for CarPlay or just for Baidu or just for Google. So we'll implement all kind of smart apps. So you have a choice whatever you want to bring in. In fact, I will not name the customer, but we are developing a very large program right now, which is designed for 4 different types of phone to operate at the same time, which is going to be first in the industry, never been done before.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what about the possibility that for mid-level infotainment, whether CarPlay and competing mirrored interfaces, that nav moves from mandatory to optional? Now I agree with you longer term, but maybe there's an interim when -- before these cars are self
componenttext: And what about the possibility that for mid-level infotainment, whether CarPlay and competing mirrored interfaces, that nav moves from mandatory to optional? Now I agree with you longer term, but maybe there's an interim when -- before these cars are self-driving when the consumer rolls into the showroom and says, "I would like to have mid-level infotainment. I like the CarPlay connectivity. But can you please keep the nav to yourself? I'm happy with my mirrored capability." I mean, a, before we get to if that's a trend or not, but maybe talk first -- assuming it might be a trend, what would the impact on your revenues and margins be that [indiscernible] nav since [indiscernible]? And then in reverse order, then B, what do you think of the trend or not -- or it's not being a trend?

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Brian, back to what I drew, the analogy of the pie. So that is basically the optionality, which means it will be from AM/FM or nothing in the car to Display Audio, where you have optionality to either ask for nav or bring your own nav, which we actuall
componenttext: So Brian, back to what I drew, the analogy of the pie. So that is basically the optionality, which means it will be from AM/FM or nothing in the car to Display Audio, where you have optionality to either ask for nav or bring your own nav, which we actually support, which is an incremental business for us because we have traditionally been in fully embedded nav and everything else. And we still do that. In addition, we are doing Display Audio. We have almost $1 billion award from a North American customer for Display Audio, and we have miscellaneous other awards from Asia. So I think that is definitely going to be the case for the next few years. But let's not forget, in addition, there's a whole lot more going in these cars. So the Display Audio might be a system architecture, but it still has a lot of software. So they're looking for over-the-air technology. They're looking for other sense of fusion. They're looking for telematics. So telematics is another new area where the new ground is being broken with a gateway approach, which is where we just won a major award with a German automaker. And that's also going to be playing out both in Display Audio segment as well as fully embedded nav segment. So market is expanding.

And for Toyota, it's actually a Display Audio, Connected Car solution award for us.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Tavis, your -- I think your third question was on the seasonality. As we look at fiscal '17, we don't see any major differences to our fiscal year '16 seasonality. Now I'll remind you of a couple of things. Our automotive sector typically has a slower
componenttext: And Tavis, your -- I think your third question was on the seasonality. As we look at fiscal '17, we don't see any major differences to our fiscal year '16 seasonality. Now I'll remind you of a couple of things. Our automotive sector typically has a slower Q1 due to some of the summer holidays. And we do then also see the APRs impact in our Q3. And when we look at our consumer business, as you're well aware, that business peaks in our Q2, which is tied to the holiday season. But other than that, we don't see any major differences to what we experienced in '16.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: And a follow-up, Dinesh, on that Toyota award. I know they've been a large car audio customer of yours for years. Is this incremental business in the Connected Car? Or is this kind of replacing existing revenues that you've been getting from that OEM?

componenttext: The question I have is regarding take rate. I think, Sandy, you said it was linear. So are we talking about maybe 300 basis point improvement from now until 2021? And what would be the swing factors for you guys to get a little bit more bullish? I think, historically, there was some discussion that it could be a little bit more of a hockey stick, but I wanted to get additional color around that. And then I have a follow-on question.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. David, I think the comment that I made about the linear expansion carries out through 2019, the periods that did give outlook for. But as we look forward to 2021, we would expect that you'll start to see a faster ramp of take rates.
componenttext: Yes. David, I think the comment that I made about the linear expansion carries out through 2019, the periods that did give outlook for. But as we look forward to 2021, we would expect that you'll start to see a faster ramp of take rates.

componenttextpreview: So yes, David, typically, starting points are so low in China, so we will see interesting good development, higher than the industry average worldwide. In that mid-segment, entry-level cars, both Display Audio and fully embedded system would grow quite we
componenttext: So yes, David, typically, starting points are so low in China, so we will see interesting good development, higher than the industry average worldwide. In that mid-segment, entry-level cars, both Display Audio and fully embedded system would grow quite well, and we are seeing good development. Actually, China performed extremely well for us for the second half. If you recall, first half was flat, and we were wondering how long will that last. But second half came in strong, giving us a full year growth rate of almost 20% in China. And Connected Car was a big driver of that growth. So we remain positive about take rates.

componenttext: Got you. And my last question, and I don't mean to be fastidious here, but were you -- was HARMAN approached by Samsung by any chance? And what would be the factors for you guys to sort of consider merging with a more technology -- not more but a technology company?

componenttext: Look, I won't comment on anybody who approached who, but I'll just cover the very high level. David, you and I will witness some very interesting development in the industry because consolidation will happen and scale plays out. And pure play like we are, what we do is very attractive thing what we do, and we always hear different things from different peoples. But we are so focused on doing what connected cars would need towards semi or fully autonomous driving, and the portfolio we are building is very attractive. So we'll see what really that means, what you just described.

componenttext: Actually, just have one question on underlying assumptions driving fiscal 2019. And Sandy, maybe this one is for you. componenttext: Yes. That's -- as we look at our outlook for the out periods, they're very much in line with what we had forecast for 2017. Maybe I'll just give you a little bit of color. componenttext: So what gives us confidence in our growth is the platforms that we have rolling on, coming out of our backlog and converting into revenue and some of the mega trends around connectivity and take rates and telematics.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I just add maybe quickly? Paresh, this might be very useful. So we guided 7% revenue growth for Connected Car for fiscal '17. Actually, you have to consider 4% to 5% we start and hold as APR. So for us to have 7% growth, we need to have right around 1
componenttext: Can I just add maybe quickly? Paresh, this might be very useful. So we guided 7% revenue growth for Connected Car for fiscal '17. Actually, you have to consider 4% to 5% we start and hold as APR. So for us to have 7% growth, we need to have right around 10%, 11% total growth. So that means we'll have roughly about 2% to 3% production, which is a reasonable assumption. And 5% to 6% of our growth will come from take rates which is pretty much in line with -- if industry will go from 27% to 30% or 31%, that's 3% to 4%. So that will mean 4% to 6% -- 5% to 6% for us to achieve our 7%. And then remaining 3% to 4% is the program expansion. So add them all together, it becomes right around 8% to 10% -- 7% to 10% and -- or actually 8% to 11%. Take out the APR and that gives you 6% to 8% range, which is about 7% midpoint. That's what we've guided.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Nate Brochmann with William Blair.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we've talked a lot about that bottom end of the pie, Dinesh, in terms of that being where the real growth can be over the next, say, decade in terms of where you can penetrate more. Obviously, in the kind of luxury, high-end segment, you've always enjo
componenttext: So we've talked a lot about that bottom end of the pie, Dinesh, in terms of that being where the real growth can be over the next, say, decade in terms of where you can penetrate more. Obviously, in the kind of luxury, high-end segment, you've always enjoyed a really nice competitive advantage. So where do you think -- when you go down to that bottom half of the pie, do you feel like that will be more competitive over the next decade in terms of trading accounts wins? And where do you think then the advantage comes from in terms of having that relationship with some of those OEs as those bottom-tier systems convert?

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So 2 things. First of all, because we are playing in Display Audio, that doesn't mean that our margins would be under pressure. Display Audio does not require complex R&D, and Display Audio is pretty much a final result of our scalable platform app
componenttext: Right. So 2 things. First of all, because we are playing in Display Audio, that doesn't mean that our margins would be under pressure. Display Audio does not require complex R&D, and Display Audio is pretty much a final result of our scalable platform approach. So we develop our platform, and we can actually implement that on multiple programs with some adaptation. So we are able to protect our margins, and we have done that over the years. However, coming back to our sweet spot is actually mid-segment. That's where we supply fully blown -- full-blown embedded systems with many other things. Now we are also adding to that telematics and many other products. And that's where margins are good because we are bringing a lot of value and new technology. So all in all, if you look at our total backlog of just Connected Car, that is double-digit profit margin in that. And when you start to flush it through the revenue line, scale does help. And by the way, we continue to take cost-reduction programs, which is a way of life. There's nothing new we announced. So with that said, we feel very comfortable in further margin expansion in this business, and also, we are selective what we take. We don't necessarily take any business. We'll generally walk away if the business does not meet our requirement. And you have heard that from me many, many times, and we have actually shown that in our results, that we are very margin savvy and protective.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And then a question on the services side. It sounds like you're getting some wins when we start looking out to '19 and can start to actually see some real revenue and some real adoption of these technologies. Could you talk a little bit
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then a question on the services side. It sounds like you're getting some wins when we start looking out to '19 and can start to actually see some real revenue and some real adoption of these technologies. Could you talk a little bit more about that curve as this moves from a little bit pie in the sky to reality in terms of moving just from a "nice to have" to a "must have" and what the real evidence of that adoption curve looks like and then also, your desire to utilize that technology beyond even the auto sector?

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Good one. So in our services business, we support -- our biggest business is automotive. Then we have also 2 other verticals, the telecom, which is also kind of merging more and more into auto side. And then we have enterprise software development.
componenttext: Right. Good one. So in our services business, we support -- our biggest business is automotive. Then we have also 2 other verticals, the telecom, which is also kind of merging more and more into auto side. And then we have enterprise software development. But staying with the overall connected business, analytics is going to play big. We have 1,500 data scientists in our company, which a lot of people don't realize. We're a powerhouse in data. And data analytics will be big deal in automotive industry. Second, Redbend we acquired, put it in our services business. I said earlier we have already over $150 million software backlog, with 75% of operating margin in it. As you start to go to the bottom and to the revenue line, you will see margin expansion. And by the way, this is a very fast development of orders. We have almost more than a dozen OEMs signing up for OTA technology. And half of those dozen are directly HARMAN customers. Other half are actually going through other Tier 1s because this technology is agnostic to any ECU. So all in all, Connected Services looks pretty promising, and that was the rationale we had. And I think we are seeing great opportunities for growth.

headline: Harman International Industries, Incorporated, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
